search_context:
### Injury Report
The game occurred on February 9, 2026 (Monday), with post-game recaps confirming statuses as of that date; no pre-game report for February 10 is available in results[1][2][3][4][5][6].

**Memphis Grizzlies:**
- Ja Morant (PG) - Out (sprained left elbow UCL)[2]
- Santi Aldama (C) - Out (right knee; injury management)[2]
- Zach Edey (C) - Out (stress reaction in left ankle; rehab ongoing, re-evaluation in six weeks)[2]
- Brandon Clarke (F) - Out (Grade 2 right calf strain; expected back in 4-6 weeks)[2]
- Walter Clayton Jr. (G) - Questionable (right calf contusion)[2]

**Golden State Warriors:**
- Stephen Curry (PG) - Out (right patellofemoral pain syndrome/right knee injury; fourth straight game missed, expected back around Feb. 11; will miss All-Star Game)[1][2][3][4][5]
- Kristaps Porzingis (C) - Out (left Achilles; expected back around Feb. 19)[2]
- Seth Curry (G) - Out (left sciatic nerve irritation)[2]
- L.J. Cryer (G) - Questionable (left hamstring)[2]
- Jimmy Butler - Out for season (torn right ACL; surgery on February 9/10)[1][3][4][5]

### Betting Lines
No current consensus spread, moneyline odds, or over/under total available in search results.

### Line Movement
No information on opening lines or notable moves available in search results.

### Recent News
The game was played on February 9, 2026, resulting in Warriors 114-113 win over Grizzlies; Warriors rallied late without Curry (fourth straight absence due to right knee), led by Pat Spencer (17 points, 7 assists), Gui Santos (16 points, go-ahead layup), Brandin Podziemski (16 points), Al Horford (16 points), and Moses Moody (15 points); Grizzlies led late but lost third straight (ninth of 11), with Ty Jerome (19 points, 7 assists), Jahmai Mashack (17 points), Taylor Hendricks (15 points, 10 rebounds), and Kentavious Caldwell-Pope (15 points) contributing; Grizzlies reserves scored 68 points (most Warriors allowed to opponent bench this season)[1][3][4]. Warriors coach Steve Kerr confirmed Curry out for All-Star Game due to knee[1][3][4][5]. Jimmy Butler (Warriors) had season-ending right ACL surgery earlier on February 9/10[1][3][4][5]. Warriors lead season series 2-0 (prior win 131-118 on Oct. 27, 2025)[1][2][3]. No other roster moves, rotation changes, or rest decisions in last 48 hours[1][2][3][4][5]. Official NBA injury report for February 10 not yet submitted by teams[6].

### Additional Context
# Warriors Bench Performance and Guard Availability Analysis

## Warriors Bench Scoring Capability

The **Golden State Warriors bench is scoring 44.5 points per game in the 2025-26 season and ranks 2nd in bench PPG among all NBA teams**[1]. This demonstrates consistent bench production, though the specific 68-point bench performance mentioned in your query exceeds their season average, suggesting that game represented an outlier rather than a sustainable baseline.

**Brandin Podziemski** leads all Warriors bench players with 645 total points off the bench for the season[1], while **Buddy Hield** holds the single-game bench scoring record with 25 points off the bench on January 20, 2026 against Toronto[1].

## Current Guard Availability Issues

The Warriors face significant backcourt depth challenges:

**Stephen Curry** (PG) is sidelined with a **right knee injury** and will miss at least a third consecutive contest[2]. He has two opportunities to return before the All-Star break, which begins February 19, 2026[2].

**Seth Curry** (SG) is listed as out with a **back injury**[2].

**L.J. Cryer** (PG) is out with a **hamstring injury**[2].

## Backup Guard Deployment

With the primary point guards unavailable, **Pat Spencer** has emerged as the primary replacement. Spencer recently signed a standard contract (after exhausting his two-way player eligibility at 50 games) and is expected to assume lead backcourt duties[2]. Over his last three games, Spencer averaged 15.7 points, 5.0 rebounds, 4.7 assists, 1.3 steals, and 3.7 made three-pointers[2]. He recorded a career-best 20 points, six rebounds, and four assists in 32 minutes in a recent win over the Suns[2].

**De'Anthony Melton** is also listed as a candidate to see increased minutes during Curry's absence[2].

## Rotation Depth

The Warriors have utilized **9 players in their core rotation over the last 10 games**, with each averaging at least 15 minutes per game[1]. This suggests adequate depth to maintain competitive bench production, though the absence of three guards (Curry, Seth Curry, and Cryer) concentrates backcourt responsibilities on Spencer and Melton.
